title: Morning Sports Update: Lamar Odom still on life support, ‘small improvement’ seen - Sports
text:
Lamar Odom remains hospitalized, Andrew Luck should play against the Patriots Sunday, and all the sports news to get your Friday started.
Lamar Odom still on life support: “Lamar Odom remained on life support and in a coma Thursday in a Las Vegas hospital, but a source close to him told ESPN that Odom has continued to make small progress over the past 24 hours. People close to Odom remain hopeful that he didn’t suffer significant brain damage in the hours before he arrived at Sunrise Hospital and Medical Center.” ( ESPN.com )
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Colts owner says Andrew Luck ‘feeling a lot better’: “’I really think that, unless something happens, I see him being a go Sunday,’ Irsay told ESPN.com on Thursday. ‘I’m not saying 100 percent for sure, but I think there’s a strong likelihood he’s a go. I was with him [Thursday], and he’s feeling a lot better.” ( ESPN.com )
Murphy lifts Mets over Dodgers, 3-2, into NLCS: “This champagne tastes even sweeter having gone through what we’ve been through as an organization these last nine years,’ third baseman David Wright said, referring to the Mets’ last NLCS appearance in 2006. ‘This city, this fan base, the guys that put this uniform on, it’s very rewarding to be here now, having experienced everything we’ve experienced.’” ( MLB.com )

— MLB (@MLB) October 16, 2015 Pedroia explains injury: “Basically, I slipped and hurt the back part of my hamstring, like the back of my knee...It was one of those things where I probably should have waited longer, but I was cleared by our guys to go. I think I played six games and it was starting to get black and blue again, so we did another MRI and they shut me down.” ( WEEI.com )
Sox fans shouldn’t lament loss of Anthony Rizzo: “The combination of hindsight with revisionist history can be especially bothersome. That mix of memory and misplaced angst has been most applied to one particular player with Boston ties this postseason. ( Boston.com )
Photos: All the times Tom Brady has beaten the Colts
Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 44, Colts 13 (11/30/2001): A young Tom Brady’s first NFL start was against the Colts, and while the defense played a central role in the victory (four turnovers, two interceptions returned for touchdowns), Brady didn’t make any major mistakes. He completed 13 of 23 passes for 168 yards. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 38, Colts 17 (10/21/2001): At halftime, the game was all but over, with the Patriots up, 28-6. The Colts had more offensive yards, but the Patriots’ defense held Peyton Manning to just one touchdown. Brady threw for three touchdowns, two to David Patten (pictured). Patten was the first player since Walter Payton to run, throw, and catch a touchdown in the same game. Matthew J. Lee / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 38, Colts 34 (11/30/2003): The Patriots entered the game with a 9-2 record. Brady threw two TDs and two interceptions while Manning had four scores and one interception. One crucial play came with 11 seconds left in the first half when Bethel Johnson returned a kick 92 yards to give the Patriots a 14-point lead. Willie McGinnest's goal line stand preserved the Pats' victory. Matthew J. Lee / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 24, Colts 14 (01/18/2004): In the AFC Championship game, the Colts had 446 total yards to the Patriots’ 402, but one extra turnover by the Colts helped the Patriots hold on for the win. Manning was 23 of 47 for 237 yards, but threw four interceptions (three to Ty Law). The Patriots went on to defeat the Carolina Panthers in Super Bowl XXXVIII. Matthew J. Lee / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 27, Colts 24 (09/09/2004): The rivals opened the 2004 season at Gillette Stadium with the Colts looking for revenge. Indianapolis led by four at halftime, but Brady's two third-quarter touchdowns to David Patten and Daniel Graham (pictured) put the Patriots up for good. Matthew J. Lee / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 20, Colts 3 (01/15/2005): For the second year in a row, the Patriots and Colts met in the playoffs, this time in the divisional round. The Pats defense stifled a Peyton Manning offense that scored 49 points in the Wild Card game against Denver. New England had a 15-minute advantage in time of possession. The Patriots went on to win the Super Bowl over the Philadelphia Eagles. Matthew J. Lee / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 24, Colts 20 (11/04/2007): The Colts and Patriots both entered with perfect records, and with 704 total yards combined by the teams, it was one of the better games they played. The Colts were up, 20-10, with 10 minutes remaining, but it wasn’t enough. Brady led two touchdown drives, one a pass to Kevin Faulk, and the Patriots went on to an undefeated regular season. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 31, Colts 28 (11/21/2010): The Colts rallied and were pushing toward a tying score late in the fourth quarter in this tight match-up in Foxboro. But safety James Sanders ended the comeback with an interception of a Manning pass on first and 10 from the Patriots 24. Manning led a strong comeback, but fell short to a long-haired Brady. Winslow Townson / AP Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 31, Colts 24 (12/04/11): The Patriots won this contest, which featured a Colts team with Manning sidelined with a neck injury, but not before Indianapolis battled back from a 31-3 deficit in the fourth quarter. Overall the Colts were no match for Brady’s 289 yards and breakout tight end Rob Gronkowski's three touchdowns. Jim Davis Globe Staff Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 59, Colts 24 (11/18/2012): After a decade with Peyton Manning behind center, the Colts had a fresh face at quarterback with No. 1 draft pick Andrew Luck. The Patriots put on a convincing show after falling behind, 14-7, in the first quarter. Tom Brady went 24 of 35 for 331 yards and three touchdowns while Luck only connected on 27 of 50 and was intercepted three times. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 43, Colts 22 (01/11/2014): Patriots running back LeGarrette Blount had a record day with four touchdown runs and 166 yards as the Patriots crushed the Colts, 43-22, in the AFC divisional playoff game at Gillette Stadium sending New England to their third straight AFC Championship game. The Patriots rushed for a team record six touchdowns. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 42, Colts 20 (11/16/2014): In a game that was billed as a battle against two of the league’s elite quarterbacks, it was an unheralded third-string running back that stole the prime time show. Jonas Gray ran for a franchise record four touchdowns to go along with 201 yards in the Patriots thumping of the Colts at Lucas Oil Field. Barry Chin / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots 45, Colts 7 (01/18/2015): A few weeks later, the Colts traveled to Gillette Stadium for the AFC Championship Game. The Patriots blew the game open with a 21-point third quarter, highlighted by two Tom Brady touchdown passes to tackle Nate Solder and Gronkowski. The Patriots would go on to win their fourth Super Bowl title against the Seattle Seahawks. Maddie Meyer / Getty Images
